p.s: John Worne's article introduces the statement that language learning is vital for the UK' future prosperity and global standing (l. 16) which will be discussed in the following.

Opponents of Worne's claim might say that it is unnecessary o learn any foreign language as a native English speaker, because it is a global language or lingua franca, so they can communicate with big parts of the world anyway.

What they do not take into account is that there are much more non-native then native English speakers which causes the English language to evlve into different versions of English, like Spanglish or Hinglish and many more.
Learning another language can help understand another English better.
On the same note, there is more than one global language.
While English may be the most imoprtant one, other languages like Spanish or Chinese are spoken almost as much, or in the case of Chinese even more, than English.
That means it is very profitabl to know one of those languages as well, also because there is a possibility that one day English will be replaced as the world language.
Another argument that opponents of Worne's claim might have is that they could just use phone translation if they needed to, which - in essence - is true, but it is not very reliable.
If you are on your way, your phone might get lost or the battery is empty or something like that and then you would not have that option.
It also does not have the benefit of giving you a better understanding of languages in general.
An important argument in favor of Worne with regard to our globalised world is the demand for qualified multilingual employees.
Knowing multiple languages can increase your chance of employment drastically, because you would be of higher value to the company which could also mean a higher salery.
In conclusion, I agree with John Worne's statement.
As shown through the arguments in this comment, it is definitely profitable to be multilingual for various reasons.
Especially because of the globalisation, it can be helpful to acknowledge other cultures and their languages.
